Hi,
Gospel's are inherently limited sets, and as such reduce the "dimensi=
onality" of the landscape. Their beneficial utility is subject to the speci=
fic objective function:)
The adages: "Crawl, walk, run" and "You have to ca=
tch them before you can pass them" seem appropriate. The ability to reasona=
bly duplicate how humans do things seem a desirable goal. Which I would cha=
racterize as "fixed concept set and customize as required". I would submit =
that a genome comprised a fixed set of inviolate concepts interconnected w/=
 evolved NN formative elements, comprise just such an instance of "fixed co=
ncept set and customize as required". I would clarify, that the word inviol=
ate is only used to denote partition from operator internal intervention. F=
urther, I would submit that this is sufficiently general to be applicable t=
o direct or indirect encodings, local or otherwise applied. And any problem=
 could be recast as such, subject only to the definitions of the concepts. =
At the heart of the issue, is the requirement, that the dimensional operato=
r disruption can not be allowed to grow exponentially with the size of the =
genome! You must find a way to prevent this, otherwise you are doomed to si=
mplicity. "Fixed concept set and customize as required" is a viable way to =
achieve this.
And practically speaking, it is not that restrictive. Imagine=
 the possibilities:
1) Start concepts defined as "best fit individuals" aft=
er a limited number of generations of evolution w/o concepts (i.e. staged r=
ecursive incorporation of "best fit individuals"),
2) Concepts defined as M=
VPRC (Multi-Variate Polynomial Regression/Classification) hypothesis models=
 on same inputs/outputs,
3) Concepts defined as highest recurring genetic m=
aterial snippets,
4) Concepts defined as instances of conventional solution=
s to problem,
5) Concepts defined as embedded human expertise,
...to name a=
 few, or combinations of all of the above.
But none of this is possible w/o=
 the added flexibility of individually addressable multi-input/output nodes=
 (IAMION). It just appears that the implications of single input/output nod=
es (SION) is unduly limiting the "dimensionality" of the ED landscape.

And=
y


--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Alexandre Devert <marmakoide@...> wrote:
>=

> Hi,
> 
> =C2=A0 You can see a module as some sub-part of some design, wh=
ich is reused. That's how engineers do, because it's the most convenient wi=
th the way us humans design, compute and build stuffs in general. Now look =
how ants or termites build shelters. They don't have a "arch" module they r=
epeat ad-infinitum, in order to build a shelter. There's definitely a notio=
n of "arch", but it's an emergent one. The "arch" is defined as a purely lo=
cal building process, local actions (ants or termites are more likely to ad=
d materials at places meeting some particular criteria) controled by local =
informations. Same goes with structures in living creatures... In purely lo=
cal building processes, the "repeated with modifications" structures are a =
consequence, it's something subjective that we see with our 10000 years of =
human engineering experience. We tend to decompose things as parts, sub-par=
ts and so on, even if they are not really existing in the actual building p=
rocess.
> 
> 
> Defining objects as purely local building mechanism is more=
 complex. It's rather alien to our engineering experience. But it also make=
s you way more resilient to noise. Put noise in the building process descri=
ption, ok, the result is likely to be just a bit degraded. Put noise in the=
 environment where the building process takes place. Same thing, result mig=
ht be just a bit degraded or might not even change (the so-called "self-rep=
airing" property).That's particulary relevent, if you use an evolutionary o=
ptimizer to optimize the description of a building process. It allows you t=
o have the much desired "small changes of phenotype =3D> small change of ge=
notype" property. In the other hand, defining things as direct assemblies o=
f parts is fundamentaly brittle, thus not really a good way to describe obj=
ects, if you want to optimize the descrition by an evolutionary optimizer. =
It's dumb builders and smart building plan (the ants, the cells, with noise=
-resilient
>  plans) versus smart builders and dumb building plan (humans).=

> 
> 
> For those reasons, I feel that most representations using explicit=
 assemblies of parts are doomed, *IF* you look for scalability and have lit=
tle knowledge of what is the optimal solution of your problem. Building pro=
cesses working on a purely local fashion sounds, where the result is implic=
it and depends on an environment, feel much more relevant to evolutionary o=
ptimization, at least for me.That was the ontogenic gospel ^^
> 
> =C2=A0
>=
 Alex
> 
> 
> ________________________________
>  De=C2=A0: afcarl2 <afcarl=
2@...>
> =C3=80=C2=A0: neat@yahoogroups.com 
> Envoy=C3=A9 le : Mercredi 23=
 Novembre 2011 3h18
> Objet=C2=A0: Re: Re : [neat] Musings On Lessons Learn=
ed From BlindBuilder Applied To NEAT & Indirect Encoding
>  
> 
> =C2=A0 
>=
 
> 
> Hi,
> Reviewed the cited sections. Seems indirect encodings could be=
 viewed as a type of user-defined application-specific module. Examples of =
module sets abound. Alphabet, Vocabulary, standardized bolts, data compress=
ion transfer functions... The point being, that the utility of module (or c=
oncept) sets, is a reduction in generic task complexity/construction plan s=
ize, etc. The comfort of the "universal approximator" characteristic, is no=
 more a rational for evolutionary development from scratch using exclusivel=
y NN formative elements, than attempting to assemble a car starting from th=
e molecular level, rather than being constrained to the utilization of stan=
dardized parts & bolts. Being constrained to a fixed set of modules/concept=
s, may not enable total global optimization, but often times, "close-enough=
" is just that, close enough. Getting close enough: optimizing based upon a=
 fixed size set of modules/concepts, and then tailoring w/ NN formative ele=
ments.
>  If the vocabulary shows itself to be too limiting, add as justifi=
ably required. But regardless of the process of how you identify the module=
/concept, those modules/concepts MUST be held inviolate within the genome, =
and thus not contribute to the dimensional operator disruption. Otherwise t=
hey are no longer modules/concepts, but rather effectively only "suggestion=
s". And their utility is lost or diminished as a consequence of their contr=
ibution to the overall dimensional operator disruption. In other words, the=
 genome needs to have the ability to be partitioned into operator and non-o=
perator regions. The non-operator regions corresponding to the module/conce=
pt interior functionality, and the operator region corresponding to everyth=
ing else within the genome. Practically speaking, this requires at a minimu=
m, nodes with uniquely addressable variable number inputs and outputs, with=
 the attendant infrastructure to handle same. Once the utility of using a
>=
  given bolt has been justified, you don't keep evolving the bolt! You shoo=
t the "bolt engineer", and move on with the balance of the task at hand :)
=
> 
> Andy
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Alexandre Devert <marmakoide@> =
wrote:
> >
> > Hi,
> > =C3=82=C2=A0Agree, BlindBuilder is a nice case of "c=
ompact encoding does not means good encoding", for the reasons you mentionn=
ed. Modules are the way to go, *BUT*... Most of time, when we say modules, =
it's some part of the genotype which is taken and grafted somewhere else, v=
erbatim. This is the level 0 of modularity, it makes tons of assumptions. A=
ssumption that your problem is nice enough to be trivially decomposible int=
o subproblems solveable by subpart of genotypes. Assumption that your probl=
em is nice enough to pave the road for you, miraculy making the right modul=
es to appear in the right order. Yes, with an optimization which is mostly =
a a biased random walk... I can go on long of that, but, well, let's remove=
 that dust on my PhD thesis and link it here (http://www.marmakoide.org/dow=
nload/publications/adevert-phd-thesis.pdf), and invite you to read from pag=
e 21, section 1.3.3, to the end of Chapter 1, which is a good summary of my=
 views on modularity,
>  with
> >  of course credit for my PhD advisors, Vi=
shnu bless them ^^
> >

De=C3=82=C2=A0: afcarl2 <afcarl2@>
> > =C3=83=E2=82=AC=C3=82=C2=A0: neat@ya=
hoogroups.com 
> > Envoy=C3=83=C2=A9 le : Mardi 22 Novembre 2011 3h18
> > O=
bjet=C3=82=C2=A0: [neat] Musings On Lessons Learned From BlindBuilder Appli=
ed To NEAT & Indirect Encoding
> > 
> > 
> > =C3=82=C2=A0 
> > Alex,
> > Yo=
ur prior work associated w/ BlindBuilder I believe is informative and appli=
cable to possible updates to NEAT and indirect encodings in general. The gr=
owing disruptive impact of construction operators as the size of the constr=
uction plan increases, seemly undercuts the benefit of compact nature of th=
e approach, and also illustrates a fundamental strength and weakness of NEA=
T. NEAT, starting from minimal size, mitigates the disruptive nature of var=
ious operators at the beginning allowing for more effective use of computat=
ional resources for growing of the organism in a profitable portion of the =
design space. But as organism size increases, the growing disruptive impact=
 of some operators, and where they are applied, increasingly bog down furth=
er progress.
> > In the context of BlindBuilder, two examples are useful:
>=
 > 1) Bridge: The concept of a bridge is simple and straight forward. From =
a construction perspective, could be achieved with a single element of appr=
opriate size and orientation. While the size of the construction plan is va=
stly different based upon the characteristics of the formative elements, th=
ough the concept is still simple, the disruptive impact of various operator=
s on form, fit, function and convergence is also vastly different.
> > 2) W=
all: Also, the concept of a wall is simple and straight forward. And again =
from a construction perspective, could be achieved with a single element of=
 appropriate size and orientation. The same comments also apply regarding c=
onstruction plan size and associated disruptive impact of construction oper=
ators.
> > The point being, that the sensitivity of the concept should not =
be subject to the scale of the formative elements, but rather the suitabili=
ty of the formulation to the objectives of the concept. In the construction=
 context, this is more straight forward. The overall objective is composed =
of a relatively few well known concepts taken together in some relative ori=
entations WRT each other (i.e. a house can be composed of four orthogonal w=
alls and a roof). The construction operators should be confined to refineme=
nt of suitability of the formative elements and their orientations taken to=
gether WRT the individual concept, guided by concept specific operator sele=
ction criteria (i.e. semi-separable multi-subobjectives).
> > Of course, in=
 the general case, the identification of concepts is not as straight forwar=
d. But efforts to identify reusable genetic material snippets would most li=
kely qualify as identification of concepts, and would thus likely benefit f=
rom: a) partitioning of the genome for application of operators, and b) app=
lication of concept specific operator selection WRT concept suitability for=
 the current overall objective.
> > 
> > Andy
> >
>
